messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 59 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: V-Learning‚ÄîA Simple, Efficient, Decentralized Algorithm for Multiagent RL

Paper Abstract: Abstract A major challenge of multiagent reinforcement learning (MARL) is the curse of multiagents, where the size of the joint action space scales exponentially with the number of agents. This remains to be a bottleneck for designing efficient MARL algorithms even in a basic scenario with finitely many states and actions. This paper resolves this challenge for the model of episodic Markov games. We design a new class of fully decentralized algorithms‚ÄîV-learning, which provably learns Nash equilibria (in the two-player zero-sum setting), correlated equilibria and coarse correlated equilibria (in the multiplayer general-sum setting) in a number of samples that only scales with maxi‚àà[m]‚Å°Aisubscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëösubscriptùê¥ùëñ\max_{i\in[m]}A_{i}, where Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i} is the number of actions for the ithsuperscriptùëñthi^{\text{th}} player. This is in sharp contrast to the size of the joint action space which is ‚àèi=1mAisuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëösubscriptùê¥ùëñ\prod_{i=1}^{m}A_{i}. V-learning (in its basic form) is a new class of single-agent RL algorithms that convert any adversarial bandit algorithm with suitable regret guarantees into a RL algorithm. Similar to the classical Q-learning algorithm, it performs incremental updates to the value functions. Different from Q-learning, it only maintains the estimates of V-values instead of Q-values. This key difference allows V-learning to achieve the claimed guarantees in the MARL setting by simply letting all agents run V-learning independently.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 59 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 59"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Minimax regret bounds for reinforcement learning",
        "Provable self-play algorithms for competitive reinforcement learning",
        "Near-optimal reinforcement learning with self-play",
        "Emergent tool use from multi-agent autocurricula",
        "From external to internal regret",
        "Swarm robotics: a review from the swarm engineering perspective",
        "Superhuman ai for heads-up no-limit poker: Libratus beats top professionals",
        "Superhuman ai for multiplayer poker",
        "No-regret learning dynamics for extensive-form correlated equilibrium",
        "Prediction, learning, and games",
        "Unifying pac and regret: Uniform pac bounds for episodic reinforcement learning",
        "On the complexity of approximating a nash equilibrium",
        "Independent policy gradient methods for competitive reinforcement learning",
        "Finding equilibria in large sequential games of imperfect information",
        "Strategy iteration is strongly polynomial for 2-player turn-based stochastic games with a constant discount factor",
        "A simple adaptive procedure leading to correlated equilibrium",
        "Nash q-learning for general-sum stochastic games",
        "Actor-attention-critic for multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "Near-optimal regret bounds for reinforcement learning",
        "Feature-based q-learning for two-player stochastic games",
        "Contextual decision processes with low bellman rank are pac-learnable",
        "Is Q-learning provably efficient?",
        "Provably efficient reinforcement learning with linear function approximation",
        "Bellman eluder dimension: New rich classes of rl problems, and sample-efficient algorithms",
        "The power of exploiter: Provable multi-agent rl in large state spaces",
        "The complexity of two-person zero-sum games in extensive form",
        "Bandit algorithms",
        "Markov games as a framework for multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "Friend-or-foe q-learning in general-sum games",
        "A sharp analysis of model-based reinforcement learning with self-play",
        "Multi-agent actor-critic for mixed cooperative-competitive environments",
        "Provably efficient reinforcement learning in decentralized general-sum markov games",
        "Explore no more: Improved high-probability regret bounds for non-stochastic bandits",
        "Openai five",
        "On lower bounds for regret in reinforcement learning",
        "Generalization and exploration via randomized value functions",
        "A course in game theory",
        "Learning to collaborate in markov decision processes",
        "Qmix: Monotonic value function factorisation for deep multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "Decentralized q-learning in zero-sum markov games",
        "Safe, multi-agent, reinforcement learning for autonomous driving",
        "Stochastic games",
        "Solving discounted stochastic two-player games with near-optimal time and sample complexity",
        "Mastering the game of go with deep neural networks and tree search",
        "Mastering the game of go without human knowledge",
        "Qtran: Learning to factorize with transformation for cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "When can we learn general-sum markov games with a large number of players sample-efficiently?",
        "PAC model-free reinforcement learning",
        "Value-decomposition networks for cooperative multi-agent learning",
        "Online learning in unknown markov games",
        "Grandmaster level in starcraft ii using multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "Online reinforcement learning in stochastic games",
        "Linear last-iterate convergence in constrained saddle-point optimization",
        "Last-iterate convergence of decentralized optimistic gradient descent/ascent in infinite-horizon competitive markov games",
        "Learning zero-sum simultaneous-move markov games using function approximation and correlated equilibrium",
        "Learning near optimal policies with low inherent bellman error",
        "Fully decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning with networked agents",
        "Model-based multi-agent rl in zero-sum markov games with near-optimal sample complexity",
        "Regret minimization in games with incomplete information"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 59 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in V-Learning‚ÄîA Simple, Efficient, Decentralized Algorithm for Multiagent RL, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
